abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Transport Rehabilitation
            Project for Serbia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            The Borrowers or Implementing Agencies (IAs) initiative
            has a greater chance to succeed than one promoted by
            International Financial Institutions (IFIs). Public
            Enterprise Roads of Serbias (PERSs ) commitment to the
            introduction of Performance-based Contracts (PBCs) was
            critical to the early success of the intervention. When such
            ownership and commitment exists, the Bank should work
            closely to support the government. In this case, the Bank,
            together with European International Bank (EIB) and European
            Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) who have
            showed commitment to the same agenda, should continue
            helping the Government of Serbia (GOS) realize that the
            cost-effectiveness of PBCs can be achieved through: (i)
            breaking up the monopoly of regional contractors who receive
            routine maintenance contracts under traditional unit-based
            contracts without competition; and (ii) introducing more
            output-based services in the PBCs. Recommendations of road
            safety audits should be directly incorporated into the road
            designs at the earlier stages of the design process.
            Contractors should have staff specifically responsible for
            implementation and monitoring of Environmental Management
            Plans (EMPs), in order to ensure compliant environmental
            safeguards implementation. Closer collaboration with the
            ministries responsible for utilities should be achieved
            prior to the start of the civil works.
